abstract.text: Learn to create, publish and use Swift package collections.

inlineContent.text: Package collections, introduced by
, are curated lists of packages and associated metadata that you can import to make discovery of existing packages easier.

Educators and community influencers can publish package collections to go along with course materials or blog posts, making it easier for their readers to use packages for the first time, or choosing which packages to use for a particular task.
Enterprises may use collections to provide a trusted set of packages, or a collection of packages consistently used by a team.
You can author a package collection as a static JSON document and publish it to the web or distribute it on a local file system.
With the
command-line interface, SwiftPM users can subscribe to package collections.
Contents of imported package
collections are accessible to any clients of
has the following subcommands:
: Add a new collection
: Get metadata for a collection or a package included in an imported collection
: List configured collections
: Refresh configured collections
: Remove a configured collection
: Search for packages by keywords or module names within imported collections
A package collection is a JSON document that contains a list of packages and metadata per package.
Package collections can be created and published by anyone. The
project provides tooling
intended for package collection publishers:
: Generate a package collection given a list of package URLs
: Sign a package collection
: Perform basic validations on a package collection
: Compare two package collections to see if their contents are different
All package collections must adhere to the
for SwiftPM to be able to consume them.
The recommended way to create package collections is to use
For custom implementations, the data models are available through the
To begin, define the top-level metadata about the collection:
: The name of the package collection, for display purposes only.
: A description of the package collection.
Optional.
: An array of keywords that the collection is associated with.

: The version of the format to which the collection conforms. Currently,
is the only allowed value.
: The revision number of this package collection.
Optional.
: The ISO 8601-formatted datetime string when the package collection was generated.
: The author of this package collection.
Optional.
: The author name.
: A non-empty array of package objects.
Each item in the
array is a package object with the following properties:

A version object has metadata extracted from
and optionally additional metadata from other sources:
: The semantic version string.

Optional.

: The Swift tools version specified in the manifest.

Optional.

Optional.

Optional.

on package signing for details.

(Apple Developer Program).

For

should be used.
For version-specific manifests, the tools version specified in the filename should be used. For example, for
it would be

Configuration that pertains to package collections are stored in the file
It keeps track of user’s list of configured collections and preferences such as those set by the
and
flags in the
This file is managed through Swift Package Manager commands and users are not expected to edit it by hand.

inlineContent.text: to establish authenticity and protect their integrity.
Doing this is optional.
Users will be prompted for confirmation before they can add an
The signing certificate you use to sign a package collection must meet a list of
. If these requirements are not met, the package manager returns an error.
For more details on the security features Package manager implements, see
While signing can provide some degree of protection on package collections and reduce the risks of their contents being modified by malicious actors, it doesn’t prevent the following attack vectors:
Signature stripping

: This involves attackers removing signature from a signed collection, causing it to be downloaded as an unsigned collection and bypassing signature check. In this case, publishers should make it known that the collection is signed, and SwiftPM users should abort the
operation when the “unsigned” warning appears on a supposedly signed collection.
Signature replacement
: Attackers may modify a collection then re-sign it using a different certificate, either pretend to be the same entity or as some other entity, and SwiftPM will accept it as long as the
To defend against these attacks, package manager has certificate-pinning configuration that allows collection publishers to:
Require signature check on their collections — this defends against “signature stripping”.
Restrict what certificate can be used for signing — this defends against “signature replacement”.
The process for collection publishers to define their certificate-pinning configuration is as follows:
Edit
and add an entry to the
dictionary:

code: // The key should be the "host" component of the package collection URL.
// This would require all package collections hosted on this domain to be signed.
// The signing certificate must have this subject user ID
To compute base64-encoded string of a certificate:
let certificateURL = URL(fileURLWithPath: <path to DER-encoded root certificate file>)

inlineContent.text: Open a pull request for review. The requestor must be able to provide proof of their identity and ownership on the domain:
The requestor must provide the actual certificate files (DER-encoded). The SwiftPM team will verify that the certificate chain is valid and the values provided in the PR are correct.
The requestor must add a TXT record referencing the pull request. The SwiftPM team will run
to verify. This would act as proof of domain ownership.
After the changes are accepted, they will take effect in the next SwiftPM release.
Since certificate-pinning configuration is associated with web domains, it can only be applied to signed collections hosted on the web (i.e., URL begins with
) and does
not cover those found on local file system (i.e., URL begins with
